plant_concentrations.Value: One year old leaves from Cinnamomum camphora trees from Taizhou, China, sampled April 20-24, 2008, contained 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether at 0.24-249.42 ng/g dry weight(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Jansson et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 12: 1163-74 (1993) (2) Crump D et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 7715-21 (2008) (3) Sellstrom U et al; Chemosphere 26: 1703-18 (1993) (4) Sellstrom U et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 5496-501 (2003)
animal_concentrations.Value: A method for multiresidue analysis was applied to pooled muscle samples of 35 osprey, collected in Sweden in the period 1982-86(1). The avg concentration of 2,2'4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether in osprey was 1800 ug/kg lipid(1). Seven pooled samples of blubber of ringed seal, collected in 1981, and 8 pooled samples of blubber of grey seals, collected in Sweden in 1979-85, were analyzed using a multiresidue analytical method. The avg concentrations of 2,2'4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether were 47 and 650 ug/kg lipid, respectively(1). Multiresidue analysis of organic pollutants was applied to pooled muscle samples of 15 rabbits, 13 samples of moose, and 31 samples of suet of reindeer collected in Sweden in the period 1985-86(1). The avg concentrations of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether were <2, 0.82, 0.17 ug/kg lipid, for rabbit, moose, and reindeer, respectively(1). 2,2',4,4'-Tetrabromodiphenyl ether levels in herring gull (Larus argentatus) brains from Big Sister Island, Lake Michigan(1991) and Hamilton Harbor, Lake Ontario(2003), respectively: 5.63-26.05 and 18.89-49.33 ng/g wet weight; 2,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether levels were 0.10-0.30 and 0.23-0.61 ng/g wet weight;  2,3',4',6-tetrabromodiphenyl ether levels were 0.03-0.10 and 0.03-0.09 ng/g wet weight(2). 2,2',4,4'-Tetrabromodiphenyl ether levels were 15.42 and 4.77 ng/g wet weight in embryo cortex and neuronal cells from herring gull eggs collected from Kent Island, New Brunswick(2006), 2,3',4,4'- and 2,3',4',6-tetrabromodiphenyl ether were not detected in the same samples(2). A 10-fold increase in 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether has been indicated in guillemot eggs from the Baltic Sea(3), with concentrations at 45 (1972) to 1100 (1989) and at <150 ng/g lipid (1997-2001)(4).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Watanabe I et al; Chemosphere 16: 2389-96 (1987) (2) De Boer J; Chemosphere, 18: 2131-40 (1989) (3) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 162. Brominated Diphenyl Ethers. Geneva, Switzerland: WHO (1994)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: The levels of tetrabromodiphenyl ether were determined in fish and mussels collected from different places in Japan in 1981-85(1). In total, 42 samples of mussel, mullet, goby, sardine, Japanese sea bass, horse mackerel, and hairtail, were analyzed(1). Seven of 17 fish and shellfish samples collected in the Osaka area contained 0.1-14.6 ug/kg of tetrabromodiphenyl ether and 3 samples of mussels from Osaka bay contained 1.6-14.6 ug/kg (wet wt)(1). Single samples of sardine, Japanese sea bass, mackerel and hairtail contained levels of 0.1-0.8 ug/kg of tetrabromodiphenyl ether(1). The other species did not contain tetrabromodiphenyl ether (detection limit <0.1 ug/kg)(1). The concentration of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether was measured in the liver of cod, collected in the southern, central, and northern North Sea, in the period 1983-89(2,3). Each sample consisted of 25 fish(2,3). The highest levels (up to 360 ug/kg) were found in the liver of cod from the southern part and the lowest levels (up to 68 ug/kg on a fat basis) in the northern part of the North Sea(2,3). The concentrations showed a decreasing trend from the southern region to the northern region(2,3). Herring collected in the 3 areas and the Straits of Dover in 1985, contained avg 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether concentrations of 8.4-100 ug/kg on a fat basis(2,3). Eels collected in Dutch freshwater (rivers and lakes) at 10 places were analyzed for the presence of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether, during the period 1983-89(2,3). The concentrations were <20-1,700 ug/kg, on a fat basis(2,3). In these marine and freshwater fish, 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether was always found as the main component, i.e., 70% of the total brominated diphenyl ethers(2,3). Fish were collected from 5 different localities along the Viskan and Haggan river system and the Klosterfjorden bay in Sweden. Muscle and, in some cases, also the liver of bream, eel, pike, sea trout, and tench were analyzed(3). Muscle tissue from bream, pike, and perch from the Viskan and Haggan rivers in Sweden contained levels of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether of 1-23 mg/kg (on a fat basis)(3). Perch from the Viskan river had the highest levels (23 mg/kg)(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Jansson et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 12: 1163-74 (1993) (2) Sellstrom U et al; Chemosphere 26: 1703-18 (1993) (3) Allchin CR et al; Environ Pollut 105: 197-207 (1999) (4) Manchester-Neesvig JB et al; Environ Sci Technol 35: 1072-77 (2001)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: A method for the multiresidue analysis of organic pollutants was applied to pooled muscle samples of 35 fresh water whitefish, 15 samples of arctic char, and a total of 260 samples of herring, collected at different places in Sweden during the period 1986-87. The avg concentrations of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether for whitefish, arctic char, and herring were 15, 400, and 59-450 ug/kg lipid, respectively(1). Bream, pike, perch, and trout from Swedish waters contained 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether at 250-750, 2000-6500, 2200-24,000, and 120-460 ug/kg lipid, respectively(2). These samples were from background and industrialized areas(2). Pike samples from a Swedish lake indicated a 4-fold increase in the same isomer from 1974 to 1991(2). Between November 1995 and January 1996, fish and shellfish downstream of sources of brominated flame retardants in the UK were analyzed(3). The concentration of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether in these samples was <1-1,294 ug/kg wet wt(3). The avg concentration of 2,2',4,4'- and 2,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether was 52.1 ng/g wet wt (range, 26.0-95.1 ng/g wet wt) and 1.7 ng/g wet wt (range, 0.4-2.5 ng/g wet wt) in 21 salmon collected from Lake Michigan during the Fall of 1996(4).

In 1997, the Washington State Dept of Ecology conducted an investigation to determine if chemical contaminants were the cause of biological abnormalities observed in rainbow trout from Douglas Creek, a small, spring-fed tributary to the Columbia River in eastern Washington state(1). The concentration of tetrabromodiphenyl ethers in fish from this study was <2.1-520 ug/kg wet wt(1). Swordfish (Xiphias gladius), samples off the coast of Calabria and the Aedian Islands in April of 2005 contained tetrabromodiphenyl ether concentrations of <4-1108 and <4-7054 pg/g wet weight in muscle and liver, respectively(2). Mussel samples taken from Thau Lagoon, France, collected May 2004, contained 307-635, <71, <70 and <56 pg/g dry weight of 2,2',4,4'-, 2,2',4,5'-, 2,3',4,4'- and 3,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether, respectively(3). Mussel samples taken from Mason Bay, Korea, collected May 2006, contained 648-11,500, 141-981, <70-671 and <70 pg/g dry weight of 2,2',4,4'-, 2,2',4,5'-, 2,3',4,4'- and 3,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether, respectively(3).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Watanabe I et al; Chemopshere 16: 2389-96 (1987) (2) WHO; Environmental Health Criteria 162. Brominated Diphenyl Ethers. Geneva, Switzerland: WHO (1994) (3) Nylund K et al; Chemosphere 24: 1721-30 (1992) (4) Allchin CR et al; Environ Pollut 105: 197-207 (1999) (5) Hong SH et al; Chemosphere 77: 854-62 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Residues of tetrabromodiphenyl ether were determined in 9 marine and/or estuarine sediment samples and 6 fresh water river samples collected at different sites in Osaka during 1981-83(1). The 9 marine and/or estuarine samples did not contain tetrabromodiphenyl ether (limit of determination <2 ug/kg). Five of 6 river sediment samples contained 12-31 ug/kg of tetrabromodiphenyl ether(1). Sediment samples taken upstream and downstream from a factory were analyzed for 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether(2). The levels found upstream and downstream were 3.5 and 840 ug/kg (ignition loss), respectively(2). A laminated sediment core collected in the southern part of the Baltic Proper was analyzed for 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether(3). The core was cut into 5 mm slices down to 50 mm depth and in 10 mm slices from 50 to 90 mm depth(3). The concentration of tetrabromodiphenyl ether at 5 mm depth was 1.6 ug/kg ignition loss and decreased gradually to 0.13 ug/kg at 40 mm depth. At a depth of 90 mm, the concentration was 0.06 ug/kg(3). Between November 1995 and January 1996, sediments downstream of sources of brominated flame retardants in the UK were analyzed(4). The concentration of 2,2',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether in these samples were <0.3-368 ug/kg dry wt(4). 2,2',4,4'-, 2,2',4,5'-, 2,3',4,4'- and 3,3',4,4'-Tetrabromodiphenyl ether were not detected in sediment samples taken from Thau Lagoon, France, collected May 2004(4). Sediment samples taken from Mason Bay, Korea, collected May 2006, contained <30-220, <30-121, <30 and <30 pg/g dry weight of 2,2',4,4'-, 2,2',4,5'-, 2,3',4,4'- and 3,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether, respectively(5).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Lacorte S et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 892-8 (2003)]
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Concentrations in rivers and coastal sediments of Portugal(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Eljarrat E et al; Chemosphere 71: 1079-86 (2008) (2) Hassanin A et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 738-45 (2004) (3) Li K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 81: 588-93 (2008)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: 2,2',4,4'-Tetrabromodiphenyl ether was reported in agricultural soil treated with sewage sludge at field sites in Spain at concentrations of 0.59-33.1 ng/g dry weight(1). Background levels of 2,2',4,4'-, 2,2',4,5-, 2,3',4',6-, 2,4,4',6- and 3,3',4,4'-tetrabromodiphenyl ether were 7-520, 6-18, 9-73, 9-79 and 11-52 pg/g dry weight in grass lands throughout the United Kingdom, at 50-1400, 9-250, 15-82, 8-86 and 13 pg/g dry weight throughout woodlands in the United Kingdom and at 12-860, 10-71, 14-67, 8-43 and 19-27 pg/g dry weight throughout woodlands of Norway(2). Tetrabromodiphenyl ether was reported at 0.006-0.472 ng/g in soil samples taken from 15 urban and 6 industrial sites in Taiyuan, China sampled Jan 2006(3).
